Summary of Contributions.
As shown in TableÂ 1,
the aforementioned paradigms
either support limited feature types
or fail to convey promising security guarantees.
Motivated by this,
we develop a novel VFL framework,
namely BlindFL (pronounced as â€œblindfoldâ€),
to address these challenges.
The major contributions
of our work are summarized as follows.

To achieve promising privacy guarantees,
we follow the analysis
in SectionÂ 4.2
to derive what kinds of values would cause data leakage
and make restrictions on them,
i.e., these values should not be accessible to
specific parties.
We summarize the restrictions
in TableÂ 2
and discuss the reasons below:

Obviously, our protocol
in FigureÂ 6
satisfies all the requirements
in TableÂ 2.
All the informative values
such as Xâ‹„â€‹Uâ‹„,Xâ‹„â€‹Vâ‹„,âˆ‡Zsubscriptğ‘‹â‹„subscriptğ‘ˆâ‹„subscriptğ‘‹â‹„subscriptğ‘‰â‹„âˆ‡ğ‘X_{\diamond}U_{\diamond},X_{\diamond}V_{\diamond},\nabla Z
are protected by either HE or SS.
Moreover, the protocol is lossless â€”
both the forward outputs and backward updates
are accurate.
To be formal, we identify two ideal functionalities
â„±MatMulFwsubscriptâ„±MatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulFw}}
and â„±MatMulBwsubscriptâ„±MatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulBw}}
for the forward and backward propagation, respectively.
In â„±MatMulFwsubscriptâ„±MatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulFw}},
each party inputs its own mini-batch data (Xâ‹„subscriptğ‘‹â‹„X_{\diamond}) and
the secretly shared and/or encrypted models
(Uâ‹„,âŸ¦Vâ‹„âŸ§â‹„Â¯U_{\diamond},\llbracket{V_{\diamond}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}).
Party A outputs nothing whilst Party B outputs Zğ‘Z.
In â„±MatMulBwsubscriptâ„±MatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulBw}},
each party inputs its own mini-batch data
and the secretly shared and/or encrypted models,
and Party B further inputs âˆ‡Zâˆ‡ğ‘\nabla Z.
Then, each party outputs the updated models.
Given these ideal functionalities,
we provide the security guarantees of
our MatMul source layer below.

First, the restrictions listed
in TableÂ 2
should also be applied here.

Similarly, we first derive the restrictions
according to our analysis in SectionÂ 4.2.
TableÂ 3 summarizes
these restrictions and
the corresponding reasons are discussed below.

The first stage takes in charge of
the backward process of MatMul,
which updates model weights Wâ‹„subscriptğ‘Šâ‹„W_{\diamond} by

Similar to the backward process of
the MatMul source layer,
Party B encrypts âˆ‡Zâˆ‡ğ‘\nabla Z
to protect the labels (Line 12).

via homomorphic arithmetics,
which is then transformed into an SS variable, i.e.,
âŸ¨Ï•,ÏˆATâ€‹âˆ‡Zâˆ’Ï•âŸ©italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ´ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ‘italic-Ï•\langle\phi,\psi_{A}^{T}\nabla Z-\phi\rangle
(Line 13).
By computing (EAâˆ’ÏˆA)Tâ€‹âˆ‡Z+(ÏˆATâ€‹âˆ‡Zâˆ’Ï•)=âˆ‡WAâˆ’Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ´subscriptğœ“ğ´ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ´ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ‘italic-Ï•âˆ‡subscriptğ‘Šğ´italic-Ï•(E_{A}-\psi_{A})^{T}\nabla Z+(\psi_{A}^{T}\nabla Z-\phi)=\nabla W_{A}-\phi in Party B (Line 14),
we secretly share âˆ‡WAâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Šğ´\nabla W_{A}
onto both parties,

Consequently, none of the parties gets access to
âˆ‡WAâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Šğ´\nabla W_{A} or âˆ‡WBâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Šğµ\nabla W_{B},
which obeys TableÂ 3
so that the model weights can be updated accurately
without any information leakage.

Indisputably, our protocol
in FigureÂ 7
accomplishes all the privacy requirements
in TableÂ 3
and the results are lossless as well.
To be formal, we identify two ideal functionalities
â„±EmbedMatMulFwsubscriptâ„±EmbedMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulFw}}
and â„±EmbedMatMulBwsubscriptâ„±EmbedMatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulBw}}
for the forward and backward propagation, respectively.
In â„±EmbedMatMulFwsubscriptâ„±EmbedMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulFw}},
each party inputs the private mini-batch data (Xâ‹„subscriptğ‘‹â‹„X_{\diamond})
and the secretly shared and/or encrypted models
(e.g., Sâ‹„,âŸ¦Vâ‹„âŸ§â‹„Â¯S_{\diamond},\llbracket{V_{\diamond}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}).
Party A outputs nothing whilst Party B outputs Zğ‘Z.
In â„±EmbedMatMulFwsubscriptâ„±EmbedMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulFw}},
each party inputs the private mini-batch data
and the secretly shared and/or encrypted models,
and Party B further inputs âˆ‡Zâˆ‡ğ‘\nabla Z.
Then, each party outputs the updated models.
Then, We present the security guarantees of
our Embed-MatMul source layer
in TheoremÂ 6.1.

Datasets.
As listed in TableÂ 4,
we use six public datasets555https://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvmtools/datasets
and one industrial advertising dataset.
We evenly divide the features for the two parties.
Since we focus on the algorithm protocols,
we assume datasets are already aligned
by the private set intersection (PSI) technique
Â (Freedman
etÂ al., 2004; Dong
etÂ al., 2013; Chen
etÂ al., 2017),
which is a general data preprocessing
in VFLÂ (Yang
etÂ al., 2019a).
In SectionÂ 8, we will discuss how to
extend our work when datasets cannot be aligned by PSI.

Apart from BlindFL, the MPC-based methods
can also achieve robust security guarantees
via data outsourcing.
However, unlike these methods,
our work is able to utilize the sparsity of features
to speed up the computation.
To verify this,
we conduct experiments to
compare the efficiency of BlindFL and
the existing MPC-based counterparts.
In particular, we consider SecureMLÂ (Mohassel and
Zhang, 2017),
which secretly shares the model weights and feature values
via ABYÂ (Demmler
etÂ al., 2015),
and performs matrix multiplication
with the help of Beaver triplets.
Moreover, as introduced by Â Mohassel and
Zhang (2017),
SecureML has a client-aided variant
that offloads the generation of Beaver triplets
to a non-colluding third party
so that no cryptographic operation will be involved
in the ML tasks.
We compare BlindFL with both variants of SecureML
in terms of the training time cost.
Furthermore, we only record the time cost of
matrix multiplication and exclude
that of non-linear activation functions (e.g., Sigmoid, ReLU)
for a fair comparison.
The results are given in TableÂ 5.
